SassyTeffie

One argument I hear from pro-choice people is that a baby that cannot survive outside the womb has no rights. The general idea that is conveyed is that even if the child is a human being it can be killed if it cannot survive on it's own. In this vein, we should them be allowed to kill anyone who is a relative or on state medical (because they are using our resources) and cannot survive without assistance. So, let's go kill everyone in a nursing home, anyone who needs kidney dialysis and is too old to qualify for a transplant, anyone on life support or considered vegetatively comatose (desipte the fact that a man recently recovered from his 13 year vegetative comatose state and is rapidly regaining the ability to function completely on his own), and anyone on welfare (after all, they can't survive without assistance). This also means that if I get tired of my children I can kill them since they depend on me for support to survive.
 
 Thoughts, anyone?

 You raise a lot of important issues with your choice of scenarios of ill adults, because we do need to make difficult and exceedingly complex decisions about when we intervene or not, but those are for another thread and I feel entirely unrelated to abortion.

I always thought the "inability to survive on its own" idea was a lame argument used by pro-abortionists, but its not that way for all of them.
 
 The others will say this when they are confronted by someone who believes a baby (however young) has the right to live from birth as a means to draw away from the facts and confuse the pro-lifer. They lead you into arguements about how old a baby has to be to be worthy of rights, what it requires, does it require consciousness and a means to feel pain in order to make what they're doing wrong and so on and so on.
 
 It leads you round and round until suddenly you're being attacked in the debate instead of you the pro-abortionist by your idea of life beginning at conception. This has happened to me several times, and I've lost my mind with it.
 
 So not only do I believe this arguement to be lame, it is also a trap to confuse the pro-lifer with issues that are meaningless if they truly believe life begins at conception.

 Fine.
 
 There have been two reasons (I've seen so far) that pro-abortionists have for using the "independant survival" arguement.
 
 1. Because they can't think of anything else to say and end up sounding ridiculous.
 
 2. Because they are confronted by a pro-lifer who believes a baby is a baby with rights from the moment of conception. They can't get through that wall, so they bring up technicalities like not having a conscience or a brain or senses. They do this to confuse the person and then challenge them on their scientific knowledge of the human anatomy and its growth. By then, the pro-lifer who is attacking the pro-abortionist is suddenly on the defense because their field in science may be limited compared to the pro-abortionist. Whether or not the pro-abortionist is really as smart as he/she claims.
 
 And with the pro-lifer looking stupid, objective viewers will begin to think the pro-abortionist is right. It's a clever weapon, but all the pro-lifer has to do is laugh and ignore it.

 OK. Let's see if I have this correct. In your view, persons who have a different opinion than you on this abortion debate in a forum on abortion, simply have no valid argument and are simply "wrong". (This is called keeping an open mind, I suppose.)
 
 If they discuss the scientific or medical aspects of this medical condition callled pregnancy, they do so only to confuse people like you who don't know enough to discuss the scientific/medical aspects. 
 
 I say with all the respect your post deserves, that is a rather childish approach to debate and to life. You might consider that not knowing something (this is called ignorance, a word that you use, in my opinion, frequently incorrectly) is a potential learning opportunity. What is the point of being in this forum, if you have this opinion?

OK. Let's see if I have this correct. In your view, persons who have a different opinion than you on this abortion debate in a forum on abortion, simply have no valid argument and are simply "wrong". (This is called keeping an open mind, I suppose.) 

 
 Uh-uh, we are talking about one specific argument here. Not all of them. That applies to everything I said here.
 
 
If they discuss the scientific or medical aspects of this medical condition callled pregnancy, they do so only to confuse people like you who don't know enough to discuss the scientific/medical aspects. 

 
 And to make the pro-lifer look dumb in the process, making the objective viewer to take what seems to be the smartest side. That's the only motive I see behind the "independant survival" arugement. Other times I can't tell if that is really what they believe or not.
 
 
I say with all the respect your post deserves, that is a rather childish approach to debate and to life.  How do you make someone "look dumb" if they are not? An "objective" observer would not "take the side" of what seems to be. That would not be objective. If one happens to have factual information about a topic, that doesn't make them "smart", that makes them informed. 
 
 Are you saying a lack of knowledge about a topic is in some way desirable or admirable? And how can one intelligently debate without all the facts? I guess you would have to debate solely on uninformed opinions or what someone else told you.
 
 

 Oh, I came here to learn. And I've learned a lot concerning both sides of the abortion controversy. 

 
 Your comments above belie that position. It seems you come here to parrot what your momma told you.

 I reply to this separately because I think it illustrate an important point. 
 You don't seem to realize that
 "you are wrong" 
 is entirely different from
 "I disagree with you".
 I think the distinction is vitally important not only to trivial online forums like this one, but to all interpersonal interaction.

How do you make someone "look dumb" if they are not? An "objective" observer would not "take the side" of what seems to be. That would not be objective. If one happens to have factual information about a topic, that doesn't make them "smart", that makes them informed. 

 
 Even if they are just informed, an objective viewer, or I should say: an objective viewer with the same amount of knowledge on the un-informed pro-lifer will think that the pro-abortionist is smarter and knows more and may even begin to believe the pro-abortionist is right. The same thing happened between someone who debated Thomas Huxley on the issue of evolution. I can't remember the anti-evolution guy's name, but he didn't know as much about science as Thomas Huxley and the majority of the people believe Thomas. Not necessarily because Thomas was right, but because he sounded smarter. That is how things work.

 You would. And it is more convincing.

 Oh my.
 How can I put this?
 That is a staggeringly inane comment. I don't know where to begin. I actually gasped when I read it.
 
 You are very confused, it seems. You appear to eshcew -or worse fear - learning new things. Just because someone has statements of apparent fact you have never heard before, it doesn't make that person smarter, it doesn't make the facts accurate and it doesn't make a valid argument.
 
 You have to think in life. 
 
 You are saying that the other guy is simply "wrong" no matter what. He has no possible argument so makes up (??) stuff to confuse the uninformed. Although you are not aware of the facts of his argument, you are certain they are false, but you feel no compunction to verify the facts, you simply dismiss them, for if they were true they might weaken your argument.
 
 This is no way to go through life, boy. 
 Uniformed is not a good way to be.
Prototype

No, uninformed is not a good way to be. And neither is being arrogant. I am speaking psychologically, and I've found that you're rage for debate and dispute for anyone on the opposite side has motivated you to think things as obvious as this is ridiculous. 
 
 And I do not tote around what my Mommy told me as if I were a delusioned idiot. Gosh, you really are arrogant. My youngest sister was born six years ago, and back then we didn't even have the internet- much less did my mother feel it was right to get into detail with me about the abortion issue. She didn't tell me how she felt during her pregnancies and the different visible problems she had coping with them because she was shaping me to be a pro-life warrior. Simone was screaming about how little I knew of pregnancies. I'm afraid she should have thought about how "informed" I actually may be.
 
 Oh, and I've seen evolution thrown left and right between intelligent men on both sides. I've actually studied what evolution is and what the theory is. I've accepted this as a theory for science. I do not, however, accept it as truth. And I like learning new things, believe me.

Your assertions are simply absurd. Too succinct for you?
 
 I trust to biology not mythology. I don't rely on the independent survival argument at all. I prefer the sentience argument. What do you have that says person exists at conception? Nevermind, I'll laugh and ignore in advance. Pooya!

 
 If you are truly interested in the scientific validity of life beginning at conception than follow this link. http://www.e-forensicmedicine.net/code.htm
SassyTeffie

Not being able to care for oneself and not being able to survive without a placenta are quite different things. Comparing a fetus at 13 weeks of gestation with care facility residents is not valid. Once "from a woman born," things are different.
 
 You raise a lot of important issues with your choice of scenarios of ill adults, because we do need to make difficult and exceedingly complex decisions about when we intervene or not, but those are for another thread and I feel entirely unrelated to abortion.

 
 How is not being able to survive without a feeding tube and not being able to survive without a placenta different? If you take away the adult's feeding tube they die. If you take away an unborn child's placenta they die. Same concept, just different terms. Subject A cannot survive without Item A, and often times a person in the feeding tube situation is receiving government assistance for this care. They are obviously a drain on society and on my personal income, since I have to pay taxes to keep them on the feeding tube. Shouldn't that mean that I have a right to decide if I want them to continue to be a drain or if I would rather have them die. Elderly people who cannot survive without kidney dialysis and are not eligible for a transplant due to their age should also be denied treatment if they are on Medicare. That money could go to something far more useful to society than maintaining the life of someone who will never be healthy enough to regain their status as a contributing member of society. Oh, that's you grandmother...too bad, I don't want my money paying for that. Never mind the fact that there are people out there who love and care for these adults. After all, nobody cares that there are people out there who would love to adopt, love, care for, and cherish these unborn children. Most of whom are willing to pay the mother's medical expenses as well.
Prototype

Sassy, you've reminded me just now of a Star Trek episode in which Kirk and Mccoy visit a planet that regularly drops their concern for anybody who is sick since they are not valuable to others without an ability to ward off sickness.
 
 I don't like the way you view people who have no capability to survive on their own. It sounded to me like you said "Let the sick die and move on to more profitable things". For as much a pro-lifer as you are, I would think you would show a little more compassion for handicapped people. 
 
 I have a friend who has a sister who is a year older than I am, but has a mental condition. (Can't remember the name) I could probably beat her in an intelligence test five times over. She might not be very profitable for society even when she grows up, but her family supports her and loves her. Would you think it justifiable if someone, in the name of society's beneficial interests, went over there and killed her so she wouldn't be draining her family's resources?

 I am not attempting to express my own views on this issue. I am trying to show how pro-choice people hold a double standard. If the reasons they give for aborting an unborn child are valid, then why don't we hear them attempting to apply these same standards and reasons to the previously mentioned situations. I'll tell you why. Because the people in the previously mentioned situations often have a way to make themselves heard, they can vote, they can do something. Unborn children have nobody to protect them except their mother, and the courts have made it all too easy for a mother to deny her child that protection for purely selfish reasons.
 
 I did not intend to make it appear as though this was my feeling on the subject. I am simply pointing out the double standards that pro-choice people hold.
Prototype
That DOES sound like a double-standard for pro-abortionists. Sorry if I offended.
SassyTeffie

That DOES sound like a double-standard for pro-abortionists. Sorry if I offended.

 
 No apology needed, I'm glad you asked so I could clarify my position.
electrolyte

If you are truly interested in the scientific validity of life beginning at conception than follow this link. http://www.e-forensicmedicine.net/code.htm

 
 Scientific validity? Let's take a really quick look at how scientific these people are... [boldface added]
 
 
Each chromosome is packed with a long string of deoxyribosenucleic acid commonly known as DNA.

 That's deoxyribonucleic acid. If they can't even get that right, it's not looking good.
 
 
This code is in the form of four chemical bases, cytosine, adenine, thymidine and guanine that are arranged in various sequences ....

 That's thymine. Evidently, these guys are ignorant of DNA; thymidine is a nucleoside, not a base.
 
 
Jeffrey's technique known as the restricted fragment length polymorphism method (RFLP) ....

 That's restriction fragment, as in DNA cleaved by restriction endonucleases. If these guys were actually educated about RFLP, they'd know what the acronym stands for.
 
 And my personal favorite:
 
The important thing to remember is that the fertilized egg or zygote contains all of the genetic material needed to create the fully expressed individual and includes inherent complex encoding for individual human interjection and all the other associated qualities characteristic of human personhood. [emphasis original]

 So do skin cells, bone cells, liver cells, muscle cells, and the vast majority of cells in the human body. If I peel off a small piece of skin, but let the cells therein die, have I committed homicide? If I donate a part of my liver to someone needing a transplant, and his body rejects the liver, is it infanticide?
